Speaker: cafeteria
Dialogue: Super-modern and gleaming. Hundreds of tables, all empty.

Speaker: hibernation bay
Dialogue: Endless corridors lined with vertical glass tubes. Inside each tube stands a PASSENGER. Eyes closed in sleep. If they're breathing you can't tell by looking. They sleep on their feet, leaning against padded supports. Straps secure them in place; sensors adhere to their skin. They wear shorts and tank tops with HomeStead Company logos. We survey their faces. No children, no senior citizens. Men and women of every ethnicity in the prime of their lives. We settle on one man. JIM PRESTON, 38. Sound asleep. A small display on his pod reads:

Speaker: james preston
Dialogue: Rate 2 Mechanical Engineer Denver, Colorado

Speaker: video stewardess
Dialogue: Good Morning, James!

Speaker: video stewardess
Dialogue: Don't worry, Jim. It's normal to feel confused. You've just spent a hundred and twenty years in suspended animation. She makes it sound sexy. Jim scowls and rubs his eyes. ONSCREEN - An animation. Happy people go to sleep in glass tubes in a hospital. The tubes are loaded onto a spaceship.

Speaker: video stewardess
Dialogue: The Excelsior is on final approach.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: elevator foyer
Dialogue: Jim finds a bank of elevators. As he approaches, the indicators blink on. An elevator opens, spilling light. He steps inside, and muzak begins to play.

Speaker: deck seven
Dialogue: A corridor lined with doors. A CLEANING ROBOT vacuums. Jim appears. Instantly the corridor lights brighten. The cleaning robot rolls past Jim.  CLEANING ROBOT Hello, Passenger.  JIM   Hello, robot. Jim follows wall markings to his cabin. Lets himself in.

Speaker: jim's cabin
Dialogue: Cozy but small. A bed, a desk, an armchair. No window. A SCREEN lights up. The HomeStead Company theme music plays. An ANNOUNCER speaks.

Speaker: cargo robot
Dialogue: Passenger James Preston?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Jim. Yeah.

Speaker: cargo robot
Dialogue: Your luggage, Passenger Jim. Swipe your shipcard to confirm. Jim swipes his shipcard through a slot on top of the robot. The robot scoots inside and deposits Jim's bags on the floor.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: cargo robot
Dialogue: Thank you, Passenger Jim! The robot zips out the door. Jim looks up and down the corridor. The receding robot is the only sign of life. He steps back inside.

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Your group's orientation starts in forty-five minutes. Join them in Conference Room Twenty on Deck One. Don't forget!

Speaker: video instructor
Dialogue: Hello, Passengers. Will you all please take a seat. Jim looks around. He's the only one there. He sits.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Can I just...

Speaker: video instructor
Dialogue: No questions until the end, please.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Wait. Where are all the other...

Speaker: video instructor
Dialogue: The Colonies offer an alternative. A better way of life.

Speaker: video instructor
Dialogue: ...thriving job markets in mining, farming and manufacturing. An explosion in the cultural arts. And if you long for the life less civilized, you can apply for a pioneer permit and seek your fortune in the wild.  Any questions?

Speaker: video instructor
Dialogue: We're all on the Starship Excelsior. Five thousand passengers and fifty- eight crew members.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: But I'm the only one awake.

Speaker: video instructor
Dialogue: No, all the passengers wake up at the same time.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Then something's wrong with the other hibernation pods.

Speaker: video instructor
Dialogue: Hibernation pods are fail-safe.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: So why am I the only one here?

Speaker: video instructor
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I don't understand your question.

Speaker: grand concourse
Dialogue: Jim finds an INFOMAT - an information kiosk. A banner scrolls across the screen: ASK ME A QUESTION! Jim taps the screen.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I need to talk to a person. A real live person.

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: What sort of person? Personal trainer? Travel planner? Therapist?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Someone in charge.

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: The Ship Steward handles passenger affairs. You can find him in his office on the Service Deck. ONSCREEN: A dotted line on the map shows how to get there.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: Happy to help!

Speaker: elevator lobby
Dialogue: Another Infomat. Jim arrives at a jog.

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: Hello! What's your quest...

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Who's flying the ship?

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: The bridge crew includes the Captain, the Pilot, the Chief Navigator...

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The Captain. I want to talk to the Captain.

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: The Captain rarely handles passenger queries directly.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Emergency, okay? Where is he?

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: The Captain is usually found on the Bridge, on the Command Deck. ONSCREEN: A helpful map shows the way. Jim marches off.

Speaker: command deck
Dialogue: Jim finds the door to the Bridge. He opens it eagerly - only to find a second door behind it - an armored hatch labeled FIREWALL and SECURE ACCESS AREA. A porthole of thick glass gives a narrow view of the Bridge. It's deserted. Instrument lights gleam in the dark.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Come on! What the hell is happening?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hello? Hello!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hello! A SOUND behind him makes him spin. But it's just a window-washer: a robot with long spindly limbs. It moves past Jim, polishing windows. Oblivious. A sign catches Jim's attention: "OBSERVATORY - Your Place In the Universe."

Speaker: observatory
Dialogue: Jim enters the planetarium of the future: theater seats facing a holographic "stage." IN HOLOGRAM: An image of the starship hangs in space. Glowing text reads "Look through the eyes of the Starship Excelsior!" Jim goes to the control podium. Touches the screen.

Speaker: observatory
Dialogue: What can I show you?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We're supposed to land pretty soon, but it looks like I'm the only one awake. Is that normal?

Speaker: observatory
Dialogue: I don't understand. What can I show you?

Speaker: observatory
Dialogue: Homestead II is the fourth planet in the Bhakti system.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Right. And how soon are we landing?

Speaker: observatory
Dialogue: Approximately ninety years.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: observatory
Dialogue: We land on Homestead II in ninety years, three weeks, and one day.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No. How long ago did we leave Earth?

Speaker: observatory
Dialogue: Approximately thirty years ago. Jim stares at the hologram in horrified realization.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I woke up too soon.

Speaker: observatory
Dialogue: I don't understand.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Neither do I.

Speaker: hibernation bay
Dialogue: Jim sprints down a row of hibernation pods. Heart pounding. Slides to a stop in front of his empty pod. Jim fusses with the controls, pressing buttons. But the screen just reads "PASSENGER DISCHARGED." Crouching, he pulls at the pod's canopy, trying to open it with his hands. It doesn't budge.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm supposed to be in there!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How do I make a phone call?

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: Your cabin telephone...

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No. Long distance. How do I send a message to Earth?

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: Interstellar messages are sent by laser array. Speak to the Duty Officer in the Comm Center. ONSCREEN: The Infomat displays a helpful map.

Speaker: infomat
Dialogue: Happy to help!

Speaker: communications booth
Dialogue: Planet and connection?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Earth. The HomeStead Company.

Speaker: communications booth
Dialogue: There are thirty thousand phone numbers listed under "HomeStead Company." What number?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I don't know. I'm emigrating to Homestead II. I have an emergency.

Speaker: communications booth
Dialogue: Division of Colonial Affairs, Homestead II Program. I have a Customer Help Line.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Sounds about right.

Speaker: communications booth
Dialogue: Begin message. Jim's a deer in the headlights. He collects himself.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hi. I'm Jim Preston. I'm a passenger on the Excelsior. Something went wrong with my hibernation pod and I woke up too soon. Ninety years too soon. I can't get back to sleep. Nobody else is awake.  I'll keep trying to fix this. Maybe I missed something simple. But I could use a hand. Thanks. Jim pushes the "SEND" button. Sits back in his chair.

Speaker: communications booth
Dialogue: Message sent.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Outstanding.

Speaker: communications booth
Dialogue: Message will arrive in nineteen years.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Say what?

Speaker: communications booth
Dialogue: Earliest possible reply in fifty-five years.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: communications booth
Dialogue: We are nineteen light years from Earth. By the time your message arrives, we will be thirty-six light- years from Earth. We apologize for the delay.

Speaker: communications booth
Dialogue: That will be six thousand dollars.

Speaker: grand concourse
Dialogue: Jim crosses the Concourse like a sleepwalker in his robe and slippers. He looks shell-shocked. He comes to the Concourse Bar: the fanciest watering hole on the ship. Black leather stools along a marble bartop. Jim touches the bartop...and a MAN swings up behind the bar - as if mounted on a hinge. A handsome fellow in a bartender's uniform - his hair and skin eerily perfect. This is ARTHUR. Jim jumps out of his skin.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What can I get you?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I thought I was the only one awake!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I doubt it. It's the middle of the afternoon. Are you drinking or not? He produces a cloth and polishes the bartop. In a startling movement, he glides the length of the bar, polishing all the way, and glides back as if on roller skates. Jim steps up on the footrail and peers behind the bar. Arthur's body stops at the waist. He's mounted on rails, built into the bar.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Android, technically. Arthur's the name.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm Jim. Arthur shakes his hand.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Pleased to meet you. What'll it be?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Whiskey, neat.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I don't know. I know some things.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What do I do if my hibernation pod malfunctions?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Impossible. Hibernation pods are fail- safe.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yeah, well, I woke up early.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Can't happen.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Ninety years or so.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: And when are all of us passengers supposed to wake up?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Not until the last two months.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: So how can I be sitting here with ninety years to go? Arthur's eyes take on a faraway look. His head twitches.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's not possible for you to be here. He smiles as if he's solved the problem.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: But I am.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sorry, Jim. My specialty is cocktails and conversation. Take your fancy trick questions to one of those Infomats. They think they know everything.  JIM Arthur, I'm in trouble. I'm screwed. I am completely, ridiculously screwed.  ARTHUR Lot of self-pity.  JIM Self pity? I'm going to die of old age on this ship!  ARTHUR Jim, we all die. Even androids end up on the scrap heap. It's not dying that matters, it's living. This is your life. Are you going to live it or lie down and die? Jim shakes his head in surrender.  JIM What do I owe you?  ARTHUR Jim, the booze is on the house.

Speaker: cafeteria
Dialogue: Machines offer food and drink in dizzying variety. Each machine has a card slot and a screen displaying its menu. Jim enters, dressed in his own clothes - jeans, a T-shirt.

Speaker: coffee machine
Dialogue: Sorry. The Mocha Cappuccino Extreme is reserved for gold-class passengers. Please select another item. Jim presses one button after another, denied each time.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Are you serious?

Speaker: coffee machine
Dialogue: Please enjoy.

Speaker: elevator
Dialogue: Jim ascends, sipping coffee and eating an egg sandwich. The doors open at the Command Deck. A sign reads "Crew Area - No Passengers beyond this point." Jim breezes past the sign.

Speaker: command deck
Dialogue: Jim prowls the floor, opening doors. He finds a room marked EMERGENCY GEAR and opens it eagerly. It's full of space suits and oxygen tanks. He peers into a red HAZARD cabinet: fire extinguishers, an axe, an epoxy foamer for atmosphere leaks - all behind glass. He opens another door marked EMERGENCY MANUALS - and smiles: shelf after shelf of waterproof, fireproof technical manuals. Jim pulls a manual labeled HIBERNATION SYSTEMS.

Speaker: hibernation bay
Dialogue: Jim sits in front of his empty hibernation pod. His toolbox beside him. The Hibernation Systems manual lies open. Jim tinkers with the electronics inside his pod. The pod hums to life. Its data screen flickers with information. Mysterious WHIRS and THUNKS. The canopy opens. Elated, Jim bounces to his feet. Strips off his shirt and scrambles in. The canopy closes over him. He assumes the position, his back against the backrest, waiting for the pod to put him to sleep. Nothing happens. He pokes at the ports where the sensors and intravenous lines used to protrude. Shakes the machine. He gives up. It's not working. But now he's trapped inside the pod. He pushes at the canopy, but it's locked shut. He pounds on the glass with no effect. Finally he loses it, shouting and stamping, hammering and raging - all muffled behind glass. Exhausted, he sinks to the floor of the pod, staring out at his tools and his manual, his discarded shirt. Then he notices the emergency release handle down by the floor. He pulls it, and the canopy pops open.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I thought I'd figure something out. I thought it would just come to me.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Stands to reason.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: But I've tried everything.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sometimes you can't catch a break. Jim gives Arthur a thoughtful look.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm your only customer, but you're always polishing a glass.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Trick of the trade. Makes people nervous when a bartender just stands there.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Okay. Lay some bartender wisdom on me. I'm lost in space here. Arthur polishes the bar while he thinks that one over.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You're not where you want to be. You feel like you're supposed to be somewhere else. Right?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You said it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Well, here's the thing. Say you could snap your fingers and be wherever you wanted to be. Back on Earth, or on Homestead II.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'll bet even if you got your wish, you'd still feel this way. Not in the right place. Supposed to be somewhere else. That's not a crisis, it's the human condition. Jim takes a moment to consider that.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's not me.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Well, maybe not. The point is, you can't get so wrapped up in where you'd rather be that you forget to make the most of where you are.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What are you telling me?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's a big ship. You're always running around banging on things and yelling at the computers. Take a break. Live a little. Jim spins on his barstool, surveying the Grand Concourse.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Live a little. When he comes back around he gives a shove. He spins faster.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: That's the spirit. Jim goes for one more shove. Misses. Falls off his stool.

Speaker: berlin suite
Dialogue: High ceilings, posh furniture, panoramic windows. The door jumps in its frame with a THUNK. Slides open. Jim enters, a crowbar in hand. A cargo robot follows him in, carrying his toolbox and suitcases. It deposits them on the floor.

Speaker: cargo robot
Dialogue: The Berlin Suite! Enjoy your luggage!

Speaker: spa
Dialogue: Jim lies on a massage table wearing a towel. A pair of robot arms emerge from the table and begin to massage him.

Speaker: z factor
Dialogue: Jim Preston! Welcome to the cutting edge of gaming! The greatest challenge you will ever know!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: All right then. He clambers into the cockpit.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: z factor
Dialogue: Begin! IN HOLOGRAM: A fortress shines on a hilltop. War machines crawl over a blasted land. Letters flash: LEVEL ONE.

Speaker: z-factor
Dialogue: You are victorious!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: z-factor
Dialogue: You are the Grand Master of Z Factor!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Another margarita!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I am beginning to learn.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: [I be study the Russian.]

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: [Good for you! It's a beautiful language.]

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You speak Russian!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Of course. We have Russian passengers.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, I'm trying new things. From now on, every time I sit down, I want a drink I haven't had before.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Fair enough. Arthur mixes a bright green drink, sets it in front of Jim. Jim takes a sip and makes a horrible face.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Something new.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: [I'm ready for today's new drink]

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: [I'm afraid I can't help you, my friend.] Jim thumps his fist on the bar.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: [Don't argue with me, robot. Give me a new drink.]

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I can make two thousand, seven hundred and thirty-eight cocktails. You've had them all. The news hits Jim like a death in the family.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: There are no new drinks.

Speaker: traveling shot
Dialogue: The robot carries Jim up and down the Celestial Promenade. Down an elevator. Past the Concourse Bar. Jim waves. Arthur waves back, speechless.

Speaker: deck one
Dialogue: The robot heads into a low hatch. Jim ducks to fit through.

Speaker: robotics center
Dialogue: A mechanical hive. Here the ship's robots are cleaned, repaired, recharged. Robots bustle everywhere - never colliding, never getting lost. A ballet. Jim's sweeper robot vomits its load of collected dirt into a waste chute. Heads into a recharging niche. Jim jumps off. He explores: it's an engineer's fantasia. Jim's eyes show signs of life. But it's a hazardous place, with cranes and platforms, hoses and blowtorches on the move. He exits through another low hatch to find himself in the...

Speaker: hibernation bay
Dialogue: Thousands of sleepers in their glass tubes. Jim walks among them, looking at their faces. Suddenly he stops, staring. Inside a pod, a woman stands sleeping. This is AURORA DUNN. A breathtaking beauty.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Who are you?  Aurora. He moves on, browsing people. Stops. Backtracks. He stands in front of Aurora, looking in through the glass. He glances at her data screen again.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Did you know ninety percent of the businesses in the world are owned by just eight companies?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Is that right?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: She's good. She knows her stuff, and she's not afraid of anybody.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Who's that?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Aurora.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Who's Aurora?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: A woman. A passenger.

Speaker: corridor
Dialogue: Jim emerges from his room in boxer shorts and slippers. He's dragging a blanket. A housekeeping robot, its dustpan quivering in anticipation, hovers outside his door. Jim taps the "Do Not Disturb" button on his door panel and walks away. The housekeeping robot squeals in frustration as the door closes over the mess inside.

Speaker: cafeteria
Dialogue: Jim pours milk over a bowl of cereal.

Speaker: elevator
Dialogue: Jim descends, the blanket draped over his shoulders like a serape. He holds his bowl of cereal in both hands.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Arthur. Say you were trapped on a desert island, and you had the power to wish somebody there with you. You wouldn't be alone anymore, but you'd be stranding another person on the island. Would you make the wish?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I don't know. I've never been on an island.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Okay. Say you figured out how to do something that would make your life a hundred times better. But it's wrong, and there's no taking it back. How wrong would it have to be to stop you? I mean, what if it made your life a thousand times better? How do you do the math?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Jim. These are not robot questions. Jim stares at Arthur in frustration.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I know how to wake up Aurora.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sounds like a fine idea. You could use some company.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'd be stranding her on this ship for the rest of her life!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Oh. Well, you can't do that. Jim buries his face in his hands.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What am I going to do?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Jim. I'm here for you.

Speaker: corridor
Dialogue: Jim exits his cabin in his coveralls, carrying his toolbox. He finds a squadron of housekeeping robots waiting outside. He taps the "PLEASE SERVICE" button beside his door. The robots zoom inside with squeals of joy.

Speaker: aurora's pod
Dialogue: Aurora's perfect lips part. She takes a shallow breath - and then a deep one. Her chest rises and falls. Her thighs shift as she bends her knees. The sensors on her body drop off and withdraw into the pod. She opens her eyes. They're beautiful. Her pod's backrest flexes, scooping up her knees as it becomes a seat. A video screen drops in front of her.

Speaker: video stewardess
Dialogue: Good morning, Aurora!

Speaker: berlin suite
Dialogue: The luxury cabin now tidy and immaculate. Jim bursts in, wild-eyed. Drops his toolbox. Hides the marked- up manual in the closet. He splashes water on his face. Stares into the mirror.

Speaker: video stewardess
Dialogue: You're ready to go to your cabin. Make yourself at home! Enjoy the rest of your flight, Aurora! Woozy, Aurora sees the other passengers still asleep.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Wait! Why are all these people still hibernating? The screen pivots to face her. The Video Stewardess points.

Speaker: video stewardess
Dialogue: Aurora, your cabin is this way!

Speaker: aurora's cabin
Dialogue: Posher than Jim's original cabin. A king-sized bed, a panoramic window. A widescreen video screen lights up. The Homestead Company theme music plays.

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Welcome to your cabin, Aurora! Your home until we... Aurora slaps the display off. Goes to the phone. A touch of her finger brings up the ship's telephone directory. Aurora selects "Information."

Speaker: phone
Dialogue: No one is available at that number. She touches other phone links, faster and faster.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: What the hell's going on?

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Passenger or crew?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Passenger. Jim Preston. He sticks out a hand. She shakes it firmly. Electric for Jim. First contact.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: I'm Aurora. Jim's lips move as she speaks her name, almost saying it with her. Aurora. She doesn't pick up on it.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yeah, I...same for me.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: The crew's supposed to wake up a month before we do. But I haven't seen anybody. Jim swallows hard.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The crew's still sleeping. They've got a special facility. I can see them in there but I can't get in. Aurora stares at him.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: You're saying nobody's awake?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Just me.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Just you?  JIM Just us.  AURORA But somebody's got to land the ship in a few weeks. Jim's finding it unexpectedly hard to deliver the bad news.  JIM I have to show you something.

Speaker: observatory
Dialogue: Aurora's eyes, wide and staring. Her face a mask of horror. In front of them hangs the starship's progress indicator - the Excelsior hanging between Earth and Homestead II. Thirty- one years elapsed; Eighty-nine years to go.  AURORA  Eighty-nine years to go.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The other passengers aren't late waking up. We're early. Aurora stares at Jim.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: We've got to get back to sleep.

Speaker: hibernation bay
Dialogue: Jim and Aurora walk down a row of hibernation pods.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Nobody strands me on a spaceship for a hundred years. I work for the New Yorker. I'll write an expose so hot you'll need oven mitts to read it. Trust me.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: It's not that simple. Putting somebody into hibernation takes special equipment. Remember the facility where they put us to sleep? Jim points at a pod beside them. A middle-aged woman inside.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Not that I can see.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: There has to be. There's always a way. Where's the crew?

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: How long have you been awake, Jim?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: A year and three months. Aurora covers her mouth. Her eyes full of horror.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Oh, my God. No. She turns her back. Suddenly she walks briskly away. And breaks into a run. Jim watches her go, astonished. After a moment he runs after her.

Speaker: hibernation bay
Dialogue: Aurora runs down a row of hibernation pods, her eyes searching wildly among the glass tubes. She turns a corner. Hesitates. Runs down another row. She's fighting tears. She puts on speed. Her sash unknots itself and her robe billows behind her.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Aurora! He turns another corner and sees her. She's sitting down, her back against a hibernation pod. Laughing at her own tears.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: I can't even find the one I'm supposed to be in. Jim extends a hand. She lets him pull her to her feet. He gives her the sash, and she ties her robe around her.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I shouldn't have told you like that.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: No, I'm sorry. It just hit me how serious this is. How did you wake up?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I just did. I woke up, my pod dumped me out, and there I was.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Me too. We have to get help.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I've sent...sixteen messages to Earth. A bunch to the Homestead company, one to the Space Administration, one to the United Nations. A couple to Homestead II, just for the hell of it. My phone bill's about eighty grand.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: How soon could we hear something?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: With speed-of-light lag, fifty-six years. That'll be from Earth. Nothing from Homestead II until we're almost there anyway. Eighty years or so. Aurora's mouth goes dry. She swallows hard.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: What about the other planets?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The other occupied worlds are even farther away. We'd die of old age before they could answer.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: What about other ships?  Jim?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I never thought of other ships.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Jim, you've had more than a year! There has to be a flight plan or something... They search the Comm Center and find a map table showing the Excelsior's position relative to the Occupied Worlds. Aurora fiddles with the controls. Interstellar flight plans appear: a spiderweb of starship tracks between the worlds.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The computer knows. Give me a ship.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: The starship Zephyr.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Round-trip message lag...ninety-nine years.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: The starship Andromeda.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: One hundred thirty-two years.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: The Maximilian.

Dialogue: Coming up. Are you getting my barstool dirty?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Got to get dirty to get things done, Arthur. If your hands are too clean, it means you're not making anything.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: And what are you making?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Improvements.

Speaker: grand concourse
Dialogue: Aurora walks wonderingly up to a GARDEN on the Concourse: a ten-foot OAK TREE surrounded by flowerbeds and green grass.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: I need you. The last thing Jim expected to hear.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Wow. You do need a repairman.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The control unit burned out. I took the one from the cabin next door. He throws a switch. The lights come on. Back to normal.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: I'm fine, Jim. Thanks for your work.

Speaker: grand concourse
Dialogue: Jim passes a cleaning robot stuck in a corner. He frees the robot: it plows right back into the corner. Another robot zooms in - and gets stuck beside the first one. Jim studies the robots thoughtfully.

Speaker: grand concourse
Dialogue: GUS MANCUSO stands at a deck steward's station, intercom mic in hand. A stocky man of 55, with a bristling mustache, wearing a crewman's coverall. Haggard and weary. He stares in consternation at the garden in the middle of the Concourse. Running footsteps. Jim and Aurora race into the Concourse from opposite directions. They see Gus and stop, astonished.  GUS  How long have you been awake?  AURORA A year.  JIM Two years.  GUS This is not good.

Speaker: cafeteria
Dialogue: Jim, Aurora, and Gus sit around a table. Gus leans heavily on his elbows, sipping from a mug.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I always get a hibernation hangover but this is the worst ever.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Two years. Ouch.  You know what it means, right? There's no way back into hibernation.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: I was hoping you'd know something we didn't.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: No. We're awake for the duration. How far along are we? You know?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Thirty-two years. Eighty-eight years to go. Gus blows air.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: That's tough.  Hibernation failure! They said it couldn't happen. And now three on one trip. Aurora shoots Jim a look. Gus doesn't notice.

Speaker: command deck
Dialogue: Gus leads Jim and Aurora to the Bridge's armored hatch. He swipes his crew card and the door opens.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You have no idea how long I've been trying to get in here.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Now you're in. Don't touch anything.

Speaker: bridge
Dialogue: The computer consoles of the Bridge brighten as they enter. Gus walks from station to station, studying the screens.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: We're on course....Whatever's wrong with the ship, NavComp's still minding the store.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What do you think is wrong?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Three pod failures? Something's wrong. Question is what. He turns to leave.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Wait. What about diverting the ship? Can we go back to Earth? Gus almost laughs.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: We're going forty percent of lightspeed away from Earth. To go home we'd have to come to a stop, accelerate back towards Earth, and then come to a stop again. It'd take as long as going on to Homestead II. Anyway, navigation's not for amateurs. Space is a big place, and a planet's just a little thing. Gus has a coughing fit. Wipes his mouth with his fist.

Speaker: diagnostic center
Dialogue: Gus opens a secure compartment beside the bridge. Inside, the Diagnostic Computer stands dark and dead.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I thought we'd see a lot of red lights here. That would mean trouble.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: So everything's okay?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: No, if everything was okay we'd see a lot of green lights here.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: What does no lights mean?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: No lights means big trouble. Diagnostic Computer's down. We've got some work to do.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What do you need?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Right now? Cheeseburger.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Never been so hungry. Worst hibernation hangover ever. Jim can't take his eyes off Gus. A new person.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: So where you from, Gus?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Grew up in Chicago. But I've lived on this ship a long time. The Excelsior's made five inter-planetary runs, and I've been on every one. I live aboard. When she makes port, I live where she lands until she lifts again.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How old does that make you?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Fifty-six.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: But how long ago were you born?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Oh. Hang on...  About six hundred years ago.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: You should rest.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I think I will.  Tomorrow morning, eight bells, you meet me beside that tree of yours. Until I figure out what's wrong with the Excelsior, you work for me. Jim and Aurora smile.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Good night, Gus. Gus waves and walks off. That leaves Jim and Aurora sitting awkwardly on the same side of a diner booth. After a moment Aurora moves over to the other side. Looks at Jim across the table.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I've missed you. Aurora stares, caught off guard. She gets up.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: See you in the morning.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: The CPU's burned out, can you believe it? Why should that happen? It's rated for five hundred years.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Can you fix it?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: You don't fix it, you replace it. There are spares for everything in storage. Make a note. Diagnostic Computer CPU. And a new cooling fan, this one looks shot.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Got it.

Speaker: grand concourse
Dialogue: Gus and Aurora stand waiting as if for a bus.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Don't take this the wrong way - I wish for your sake you were still asleep - but I'm glad you're here.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Thank you, sweetheart. A GROWL of gears. Jim drives up in his souped-up golf cart.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The golf cart. Gus takes in the bank of batteries, the giant tractor wheels.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: This I like.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Next bay is the ship's stores. So how fast can she go? Jim puts the pedal down. The cart lays rubber on the deck plates and shoots down the aisle while Aurora and Gus yell.

Speaker: ship's stores
Dialogue: Up on a hydraulic lift, Gus digs components out of storage. Hands them to Aurora, who hands them to Jim, who loads them into the cart.

Speaker: diagnostic center
Dialogue: Gus works on the Diagnostic Computer while Jim looks on. Nearby, Aurora thumbs through Gus's technical manuals. Gus clamps a final component in place and nods at Jim.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Start `er up. Jim closes a circuit breaker and powers up the computer. A deep electrical HUM as the machine boots up. The screen flashes a message: RUNNING VESSEL DIAGNOSTIC. A progress bar shows that the diagnostic is 0.0% complete. The lights on the indicator panel remain dark. The first light begins to flicker as the diagnostic runs.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How long will it take?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Full diagnostic from a cold start? Days. But it'll tell us everything.

Speaker: grand concourse
Dialogue: Gus strolls through the ship, looking around nostalgically. He passes Jim's garden and shakes his head.

Speaker: concourse bar
Dialogue: Gus walks up to the bar.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Chief Mancuso! Good to see you.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Good to see you too, Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What can I get you?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Just an ice water with a little lemon. I feel hot as hell. Gus mops sweat from his brow and sips his water. His hand trembles hard enough to rattle the ice cubes.

Speaker: gus's cabin
Dialogue: A homey space, filled with Gus's possessions: pictures of fellow spacers and vacation spots on half a dozen planets. Books, keepsakes and mementos. Gus sits on his bed, on a handmade quilt. Coughs violently into a handkerchief, leaving the cloth spotted with blood.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Thank you. Gus arrives in a fresh coverall, a steaming mug in hand. No signs of frailty. He hands each of them a digital slate.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: All right. Last night I checked ten atmosphere stations and two of them were burned out. Twenty percent failure rate. Unheard of. So we're going to see how far the rot runs.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Got it.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I'm going down to the Hibernation Bay to look at our pods. Maybe I can spot what went wrong. Jim and Aurora exchange glances.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: That should be interesting.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Son of a gun. A sound behind him. Gus turns to find Jim watching. He looks from Jim to the pod mechanism and back again.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I finished.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I looked at your pod. Very simple. The clock chips burned out. Not supposed to happen, but it's simple. Jim fidgets. Starts to speak. Gus cuts him off.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Gus...

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: You did this.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I was thinking what a lucky son of a bitch you were, stuck with a beauty like Aurora. But it wasn't luck.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No. Gus sits down heavily, looking at Jim.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: She knows?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: She knows. Gus thinks that over, shaking his head at the idea.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I could see there was some trouble between you. Gus starts putting his tools away. Jim lays the electronic slate down beside him.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Here's your inventory. I'll be in the machine shop if you need me.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: I finished the census.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: So you know. What Jim did. Aurora's chin begins to tremble.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Yeah, he told me.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: He told you? Just like that? And? She waits, trembling with righteous indignation. Gus doesn't want to get into this: he looks away uncomfortably.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: No, it's a bad thing. But...  Look. When a drowning man drags somebody down with him, you don't call it right. But he's drowning. A starving man steals a loaf of bread, what can you say? You should have starved?

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: I would have starved.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Really? Aurora looks hard at Gus, thinking, and says nothing.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: By Aurora's count, about thirty percent of the atmosphere station CPUs are burned out.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We can replace them.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: We will. But they'll just burn out again if we don't figure out why it's happening.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Where do we start?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: We wait for the diagnostic report. You've been knocking around this ship for two years. A few days more won't kill you. Gus hacks and coughs. For a moment his weakness is plain to see...but robots sweep in and lay dishes on the table. Gus sets his slate aside.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: So how did you end up in space?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Only place I ever wanted to be. When I was sixteen I lied about my age and got onto a lunar shuttle crew. A few years later I moved on to planetary ships. Made the Venus run a hundred times, then Jupiter and Saturn. Then the gravity drive came along. Real spaceflight. I did everything I could to get onto an interstellar ship. I was thirty-six years old the first time I saw an alien sun. No going back after that. I've walked on seventeen planets in five solar systems.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's incredible.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Don't you feel homeless?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I'm a spacer. My home is where I am. You can't take much with you, so you don't get hung up on things. You have yourself. The things you do. The company you keep. Gus pushes himself off his stool. Momentarily shaky, he pulls himself together. He takes a seat at the grand piano and plays - a fine beerhall pianist. Gus touches a switch and lifts his hands: the piano keeps playing. Gus stands and extends a hand to Aurora. She takes it, and Gus sweeps her across the floor. Jim watches from the bar.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Gus always dances with the ladies.

Speaker: gus's cabin
Dialogue: Gus lies feverish and semi-conscious in his bed. A THUNK! The door slides open. Jim and Aurora rush in.  JIM Gus! Are you all right?  GUS No. No, I'm not.

Speaker: infirmary
Dialogue: Gus lies in a medical scanner. Jim and Aurora watch as the machine bathes Gus in light, sensors floating over his body.  GUS Couldn't get up. Weak as a baby. What does it say is wrong with me? The scanner's display screen lists not one diagnosis, but hundreds: disorders, diseases, dysfunctions.  JIM  It's a few things.  MEDICAL SCANNER Diagnosis complete. Gus hauls himself out of the scanner. Pulls a bathrobe on and comes around to look at the screen. He sees it and blanches.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: What's the summary?

Speaker: medical scanner
Dialogue: Pan-systemic necrosis. Progressive organ failure. Cause unknown.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I'll tell you the cause. My goofy hibernation pod is the cause.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: What's the treatment?

Speaker: medical scanner
Dialogue: No treatment known. Gus pivots the monitor so that only he can see it.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Prognosis. A series of images flickers over the screen, casting shadows on his face. Gus swallows hard and looks away.

Speaker: medical scanner
Dialogue: Between two and three days. A long moment of silence. Gus turns and exits.

Speaker: corridor
Dialogue: Gus settles himself behind the wheel of Jim's cart.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Gus!

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Sorry, Jim. Gus puts his foot down and the cart squeals away.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: He's not in his room. Aurora flips on the intercom, speaks into the mic. Her voice resonates through the ship.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Where are you? Gus, please answer. We'll be at the Concourse Bar every hour. I'm really worried.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Where is he? What's he doing?

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Where have you been?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Making arrangements. You kids have dinner plans?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Xanadu at eight.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: You look magnificent.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How you feeling?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Fine, fine.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Gus, just because some stupid machine says there's no cure...

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: State-of-the-art machine, Aurora. Anyway, I can feel it happening.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: But you just got here. It's barely been a week. He takes her hand.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: No point counting the days.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: A pure oxygen environment is about as dangerous a place as you can be. A steel pipe will burn in pure O2. And there I am with a hammer, trying to close this valve and stop the oxygen flow, when one spark will kill us all. But the thing is, O2 makes you punchy. So I can't stop laughing. And then the guys behind me start in, and soon everybody's going. Captain's giggling like a girl. The Navigator pissed his pants laughing. Jim and Aurora laugh. But pain contorts Gus's face. He grips the table with white knuckles. And nobody's laughing anymore.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I went through the ship's manuals and made notes wherever there was something special you should know. These should keep you straight. In a few days the Diagnostic Computer will show you what needs fixing. He takes his shipcard from around his neck. Hands it to Jim.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Why are we standing by the airlock?

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Oh, God! Gus, no!

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Got no choice about going. But I can decide how to go, and I'm going out on my own two feet.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: If you knew how this feels, Jimbo, you wouldn't ask me to stay. Gus extends a hand to Aurora. She throws her arms around him.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Gus. I can't stand it. There's got to be some other way. Don't do this. Gus gently frees himself from her arms.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: And take care of each other. Gus turns and opens the airlock. He straightens, squares his shoulders, and steps inside. Turns to face them.

Speaker: robotics center
Dialogue: Jim walks in.   Everywhere robots bunch and stumble. A pair of sweeper robots fight to enter the same recharging niche. They trip up a procession of gangly window washers - who stumble into a parade of robot waiters. Chaos spreads. The robots' clockwork perfection upset.

Speaker: cafeteria
Dialogue: Aurora draws a glass of orange juice and gets green sludge. Dials for toast and gets two slices of charcoal.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: There's trouble everywhere. Atmosphere systems, water systems, waste systems, robot control.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's happening? Aurora goes to the worktable: its surface displays the diagnostic report. Thousands of faults and failures.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: It started two years ago. Thirty years with no trouble, then forty- seven failures in a single day.  Structural concussion. System overvoltage. Transient pressure anomaly. Circuit reset, conduit 12.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Pod 1498? That's me!

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Whatever happened that day woke you up. She pulls up a graph of failures over time: A trickle of breakdowns that swells into a torrent.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Ever since then, more and more failures. Faster and faster.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: How do we find out what's going on?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We start at the beginning. The breakdowns from the day I woke up. Aurora brings up a map of the ship on the display. Red markers blink on the map.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: They're all on Deck One.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Power Converter seems okay.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: The failures are all below us.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: It's beautiful.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Scares the hell out of me.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: What keeps it in?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Gravity. The gravity plant gives us weight. Propels the ship. And it contains the fusion reaction. All one system. Aurora watches Jim as he walks among the consoles, studying the instruments.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: The cluster of failures is still one level down.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: This should be it. Jim cards the door with Gus's shipcard. The lock flashes a red light and stays closed.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Gus's card should open any door.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Let me try an override code. She squeezes past Jim. Taps at the door's keypad. Jim peers through the narrow window in the door.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Wait a sec, maybe there's a reason the door... The light flashes green. The door begins to slide open. A HOWLING WIND sucks Aurora against the crack in the door. She screams. Jim grabs at her. A hurricane drags her inside.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Jim. Are you okay?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I think I'm all right.  Look. In the center of the room a round column houses the CORE COMPUTER. There's a CRATER blasted in the machine.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: A meteor.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: A rock. They stare at the meteor: the cause of it all. A BEEP: on the Diagnostic Computer's console, more green lights turn red. New errors pop up on the diagnostic report.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: And every computer that burns out increases the load on the others.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yeah. The breakdown accelerates. If we don't stop it, the whole ship will go down.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: I'm trapped on a sinking ship?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Gus said there's spares for everything. If we replace the core computer, it'll pick up the load. The burnouts will stop. Another BEEP. Another green light turns red.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Let's go.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Two more rows, then left! The cart squeals around a corner.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: First you connect the data bus, then the sync cable, then bridge the power and backup power...you're supposed to run a startup checklist, but Gus made a note. He says you can skip straight to power-up as long as you...

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: You just got sucked into outer space. Take a break.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Aurora!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We've got to get you down. The gravity might come back on. Aurora hadn't thought of that. She looks down fearfully. Jim swings over the railing. Braces his feet. Takes aim.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Whoa. Hey. Let's talk about this.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hang on.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: To what?! Jim dives at her like Superman. Wraps his arms around her. They tumble through space until Jim grabs a railing.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: There's no gravity.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yeah. That's bad.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Why is there no gravity?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The gravity plant's failing. Internal field goes first. After that the engines die...then the fusion reactor goes nova.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: That is bad.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We've got to get the core computer online. Now.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The engines just shut down.

Speaker: fusion reactor
Dialogue: The caged sun boils and swells. Tentacles of flame graze the reactor walls, leaving charred trails.

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Reactor failure. Reactor failure. Passengers please remain calm. Aurora holds the computer in place, gripping two handholds, her shoulder planted against the machine.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Does the data cable go in the "bus" port or the "through" port?

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Bus port! The blue one! The ship shudders violently, throwing them from side to side. Jim forces one cable after another into their sockets. Aurora tires: the computer slides out of place.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hold it! Hold it!

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Trying! She strains. The computer slides back into place. Jim closes the last connection. Slips out of the niche and lowers the clamps that hold the computer in place. He throws the heavy power lever. The lights go out.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: What's happening?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Don't know. The core computer flashes to life. The lights come back on. So does the gravity. Jim and Aurora slam to the floor. Inches away, the old computer plunges down and embeds itself in the deck. Across the room the golf cart bounces on its tires.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's so funny?

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: We're alive! The engines rumble back to life. A distant, rhythmic sound begins: BOOM-CHAK...BOOM-CHAK...

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We have to replace the other burned- out computers. But we have time. Aurora slides her arm around his waist.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Jim! He turns. Stares in shock as more pods drift past the window.

Speaker: hibernation bay
Dialogue: Jim and Aurora sprint into the facility. The sound is loud here: BOOM-CHAK...BOOM-CHAK... It's the sound of hibernation pods being ejected. The wave of ejections marches down an aisle: one pod after another disappearing into the ceiling. Jim rushes to a CONSOLE. Scans the display.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The hibernation system rebooted. It thinks the ship's in port. It's ejecting the empty pods.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: They're not empty.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Who's that?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The Captain. The sounds of the ejection wave come closer. Boom-chak.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: You don't have much time.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's the last of the burned out processors. When it reboots we should be all green.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: Can we talk?

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: You know, if it wasn't for you waking me up, I'd be drifting out in space right now with the others. And if you'd never awakened, the whole ship would have been lost while we slept. Jim shakes his head at the tangle of it.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I've missed you too.

Speaker: aurora
Dialogue: I don't want to be angry anymore. I can't be. We've come through too much. No matter what you've done... the fact is, I love you. Jim reaches out and takes her hand. She watches him intertwine his fingers with hers. Aurora gazes out at the stars - the endless shining sky that enfolds them. She looks at Jim and smiles.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hell of a life.
